subject: Re: [junit] number of test classes for one target class
msgSnippet: ... Should be ? No. But you may learn something by doing this way to start. People often ask, Do I need to write all these tests? We usually answer, Only
messageBody:
Masashi Nakane wrote:

>
> Hello ,people
>
> I just started to use Junit.I like this.
>
> But, When I am writing a test code , i am wondering
> how many test classes to one target class.
>
> Suppose that I have a target class named as SamuraiDAO,
> and it has 10 public methods to be tested
> and each method has 15 test cases.
>
> then it makes that the tese class named of SamuraiDAOTest
> has 150 test methods !!! its not easy to maintain test code,
> because I wrote many comments about test case details as well.
>
> So , i am thinking about splitting the test class SamuraiDAOTest
> to liek SamuraiDAO4methodMediationTest and
> SamuraiDAO4meditatemethodTest ,SamuraiDAO4fightmethodTest and so on.
>
> BUt, Im not sure that is good idea or not.
> Is this a bad practice to split?


> Target classs and Test Case class should be 1 to 1 ?

"Should be"? No. But you may learn something by doing this way to start.

People often ask, "Do I need to write all these tests?" We usually
answer, "Only if you want the code to work." Until you know better (have
more experience), it is worthwhile to write more tests than fewer tests.

That said, if you notice that ten tests do essentially the same thing,
then you have uncovered some duplication in your production code! If you
can remove the duplication, then you can reduce the number of tests,
possibly down to one. This is a very common pattern in adding tests to
code without tests.

The Data Access Object is a perfect example of a class that tends to
have /massive amounts/ of duplication, making it look more difficult to
test than it could be. I write about this in chapter 10 of _JUnit
Recipes_. (www.manning.com/rainsberger)

I also write about how to organize test cases into fixtures (= test case
classes) in chapter 3.

Your line of thinking is good: one test case class per /method/ being
tested. Try it. I don't recommend using numbers in the names. Instead,
try these test case class names:

SamuraiDAOFightTest
SamuraiDAOMeditateTest
...

You'll notice some duplication. Use the usual techniques (Extract
Method, Extract Superclass) to remove that duplication. If you're not
familiar with refactoring, then buy a copy of "Refactoring: Improving
the Design of Existing Code" /now/. Don't look at the price of the book.
It'll return its value in the first week.

Good luck.
